narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Calculus.
I learned the more intense part of single variable calculus.
This course covered calculus BC, and that is the material I learned. Having taken BC calculus before but placing into this class, the class didn't add a lot to my knowledge.
I improved my critical thinking and mathematical problem solving skills throughout this course. My mathematics understanding also improved generally throughout the term.
I learned foundational calculus at a college level. We learned about integration strategies,  the convergence/divergence of series, parametric equations, and polar coordinates.
I learned much about the topics covered in Calculus 2. I learned how to effectively absorb the material taught on an online setting, which was different from any math class I had taken before.
I learned how to use the textbook to help with the content.
Many additional skills and topics to Calculus AB. Finding volumes, error bounds, and much more.
Review of what was taught in Calc BC
I practiced my Calculus knowledge and revised various formulas and study methods.
I learned how to do many aspects of calculus
I furthered my knowledge in Calculus, necessary for my future studies in the field of economics.
In this course, we covered a variety of topics in single variable calculus, including Riemann sums, integration, series behavior, and polar coordinates.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish the lectures were recorded because at times I needed to see how the teacher explained how to do a problem in class because the homeworks and exams were much harder problems.

There is a huge amount of variation between the quality of the different instructors of the course. Some are wonderful teachers, and others aren't as much. It would be great if there was a higher standard of teaching skills across all sections of the course. The instructors weren't great about adding grades to Canvas, so I was never totally sure of where I stood in the class They didn't upload exam grades to Canvas, didn't tell us our new percentage grades when a midterm was curved, and stopped uploading pset grades to canvas about halfway through the course. Additionally, the grading for tests and psets was wildly inconsistent. I was given half credit on one problem, and after consulting with my instructor, they said they would have given me full credit for it. Incidents like these gave the impression that the class wasn't about gaining any genuine understanding of calculus, and was more about writing things out and hoping the instructors would be in a good mood when they graded it.
The virtual aspect of the course adds to the difficulty of fully engaging with and learning new math; however, it was nice having so many virtual study sessions that were recorded for reference.

I think the strength of this course was that it was clear and provides good and in-depth foundation for higher level mathematics courses. However, I think that this course may be significantly more engaging in person as one can collaborate with other students in person and work on problems together; this is difficult to emulate in a course like this over zoom.
This course was well-structured and I felt like I had the tools to prepare for each exam. I wish study sessions before exams were in smaller groups so they could be more interactive.
The course was good in making sure to cover the material necessary to complete math 115, but we could have spent more time on the material we needed to get through and less time on questions.
Strengths were the available resources to learn the material.
A strength was the office hours and a weakness was that the professor went too fast often times

I believe that the overall course is strong. Perhaps in some instances, the covered material was quite difficult to grasp in the short amount of time that is given in the lectures. I often found myself referring to the textbook to learn and understand the material, rather than the lectures.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think learning math on zoom is much more challenging, but there is not really a way to combat this.

Virtual lectures were not particularly engaging, and it was sometimes difficult to follow along with the notes the professor was taking while screensharing. The process of taking exams and psets and explorations worked out pretty well though.
The virtual aspect of the course adds to the difficulty of fully engaging with and learning new math; however, it was nice having so many virtual study sessions that were recorded for reference.

I think that the canvas page of the course was very clear in stating upcoming deadlines. Instructors were always on time, and peer tutors had a very clear schedule that could easily be followed. However, the lectures were never recorded. This may be difficult for students in different time zones.
Virtual lectures were successful though class participation over zoom was a bit lacking. It may have been helpful if we used the 'raise hand' function to encourage more participation.
The course succeeded in showing the material through the screen share feature, which was much improved after switching from share screen writing on a computer to an iPad.
I liked the online learning and having access to the professors notes after class.
The patience in teaching this course and just math online was great and a comfort for students who needed to ask questions.
The class itself would have probably been better in person but the office hours were easier to get to.

I believe that the lectures would understandably be more engaging if held in person. From my experience, the virtual aspect somehow made the exams even more stressful because I always encountered some technical difficulties. Nevertheless, I believe that the employed practices were very appropriate in the face of the pandemic.
I liked how the office hours took place over zoom, because it allowed me to stop by to discuss the week's pset even if I had another meeting immediately after.
i liked the live lecture but also maybe recorded would be easier so we could pause it when we are trying to process information

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes.
Yes. I would suggest taking it in person to really get to know the professor and make it easier to get help.

I would only recommend this course to another student if they really needed it as a prerequisite for something. As a class, it wasn't particularly engaging or informative. As someone who didn't need it as a prerequisite, I regret taking it.

Yes. I think that overall, this course does provide good foundational background for Calc II. The topics were explored in depth and were clear, and I think it provides good foundation for higher level math courses.
No, it was pretty rough and went super fast.
I would recommend this course. I gained a good foundation in calculus and I feel prepared to move forward to multivariable calculus.

I would recommend this course to another student interested in math as the material was not too challenging, the workload was not too great and we got through a good amount of material in a short amount of time.
I would recommend the course if calculus was needed for future goals.

not unless you have to take it for requirement; I felt that the notes were very unorganized and the main idea of each notes was never conveyed properly. Also, there was not enough practice and professor had difficulty explaining concepts thoroughly.

The course workload is infinitely greater and far more than what is truly necessary to understand the concepts. In addition, one or two questions on exams are always extremely difficult in comparison to the textbook problems. Otherwise, the resources provided on Canvas, including the concept reviews and sectional practices are very helpful + provide great feedback.
A great foundational course!
If they need a math requirement it is a good class
I would recommend this course since it serves as a great prerequisite for some of the other courses one might have to take, or if someone is interested in pursuing math as their major.

I would recommend this course, as it provided a good overview of some of the fundamentals of calculus. If you are interested in Physics and have not already covered the material in this class in high school, it will be very helpful to understanding some of the coursework and concepts.
Yes, helps you gain a general and a deep understanding of Calculus II.
